title: Putting TIGHTS face mask makes better stopping spread Covid study finds
story: Share this articleThese included talking, turning their head side to side, bending over, smiling, nodding, and breathing normally and heavily.The researchers measured how well the masks fit by monitoring the filtration efficiency and calculating a 'fit factor' score. The results show better fitting masks have fewer gaps between a person's face and the edge of the mask, ensuring the air inhaled is filtered through the mask. Pantyhose and cloth tape were most effective at improving how well the KN95 mask fit, increasing the fit factor by 27.7 and 14.7, respectively.Meanwhile, using gauze to stuff the gaps between the face and KN95 masks only offered a 'minor improvement' of 2.7. And using gauze on top of the KN95 covering barely improved the fit (1.6). Tying the earbands of the KN95 mask only improved the fit by 0.8 — because they already fit so tightly.Surgical masks performed better if worn in combination with pantyhose (7.2) or if the gaps were sealed using cloth tape (4.8).Rubber bands and tying ear bands (2.5) were the least effective way of getting a surgical mask to fit better, but still offered more protection than wearing the mask alone.  However, the researchers noted many of the hacks, including the most effective ones, were uncomfortable. Rubber banks put pressure on the ears and face and reduced blood circulation to the ears for some people. Meanwhile, pantyhose gave volunteers 'high levels of discomfort', caused problems speaking and sometimes covered the participants' eyes during the exercises. And while fabric tape was comfortable to wear, it was uncomfortable to remove and the researchers noted sweat or movement over time could dislodge the tape.But they noted that the hacks are 'accessible to the general public' and could help health workers, who commonly wear both surgical and KN95 masks, modify their mask to gain more protection.The findings could also help designers to improve masks and mask fitting devices, the team said. Face masks are no longer legally required in England after the restriction was lifted last month. However, some transport providers, such as Transport for London, and shops, including Sainsbury's and Tesco, still require customers to wear coverings. And masks are needed in certain venues, such as shops, pubs, restaurants and gyms in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. Face mask fit hacks: Improving the fit of KN95 masks and surgical masks with fit alteration techniques

title: citizens assembly set to examine possibility of directly elected mayor for dublin
story: Taoiseach Micheál Martin is to brief Cabinet on plans for the two citizens assemblies, set to start in April. Photograph: Brian LawlessPA WireThe possible introduction of a direct election for the position of Dublin’s mayor is to be examined by a citizens’ assembly later this spring, under plans going to Government this week.Taoiseach Micheál Martin is to brief Cabinet colleagues on plans for two citizens’ assemblies, set to start in April.The main item that will be referred to the Dublin citizens’ assembly is to consider whether a directly elected mayor for the city should be considered, as well as issues relating to the local government structure.The assemblies will be asked to report back within nine months, it is understood.The Programme for Government commits to establishing a citizens’ assembly to consider the type of directly elected mayor and local government structures best suited for Dublin, as well as to allow for plebiscites to be held in 2024 in any local authority that wishes to have a directly elected mayor.Previous plans for a directly elected mayor for the capital fell apart when Fingal County Council rejected the plans, which needed the support of all four local authorities in the capital to proceed.Limerick will get a directly elected mayor with executive powers and a salary of €130,000, after voters in the city approved the proposal in a plebiscite in 2019. title: austria passes covid vaccine mandate but question marks linger over enforcement
story: Austria becomes the first European Union country to make Covid-19 vaccination legally compulsory for adults. Photograph:  Joe KlamarAFP via Getty ImagesAustria has become the first country in the EU to make vaccinations against Covid-19 mandatory for all adults, but questions remain over whether it can sway those sceptical of taking the jab and how much the Alpine state’s government is willing to press those who won’t comply.The upper house of the Austrian parliament, the Bundesrat, on Thursday evening voted 47-12 in favour of a general vaccination mandate, formally approvinga law that will see those over the age of 18 who decline to take a jab face penalties of up to €3,600, unless they are pregnant or severely ill.The legislation, which was signed by Austria’s president Alexander Van der Bellen on Friday and will come into effect over the coming days, has been followed with great interest across Europe, where other nations have considered taking a similar step. Already approved by the lower house of Austria’s parliament with a clear majority last month, Austria’s vaccine mandate is due to come into effect in three stages.Every household is to be informed of the new law via post by March 15th, after which police will start monitoring people’s immunisation status via spot checks and issuing fines of €600, rising to up to €3,600 in case of noncompliance.In the third phase, those who cannot show proof of vaccination by a certain deadline are to be automatically fined, but it is unclear whether the government still keen to enforce its mandate to such a degree.In an interview with public broadcaster ORF on Thursday morning, health minister Wolfgang Mückstein was unable to give a date for the crucial deadline.As Austria has inched closer to a decision on mandatory vaccinations, the conservative-Greens coalition government of chancellor Karl Nehammer has simultaneously loosened restrictions for the unvaccinated.A “lockdown for the unvaccinated” was lifted on Monday, and shops, restaurants and hotels across most of the country will soon be able to receive visitors who haven’t got a jab, as long as they can show a recent negative test result.Political developments around the mandate have been followed closely in Germany, where government calls for a similar law have become more cautious in recent weeks.“Since the government announced the compulsory measure in mid-January, it has done everything to undermine, soften and make its own project redundant,” wrote Munich-based German newspaper Süddeutsche Zeitung in a comment piece. “The message is clear: we didn’t really mean it.”Gerald Loacker, a health spokesperson for liberal NEOS opposition party, said waning political enthusiasm for mandatory vaccinations was impossible to ignore.“What we are dealing with here is a vaccine mandate that comes into effect just as the government is making it possible for those who aren’t vaccinated to enter a bar with a subsidised free test result and raise a glass to their resistance,” Loacker said.“That’s not a coherent policy, and people in Austria are taking note of that.”Karl Stöger, a professor of constitutional law at Vienna university, said that seeming incoherence was partly a deliberate choice. “The vaccination mandate has legal teeth, but it is also a law that is very aware of the limits of what a state can force people to do,” he said.Stöger, who has advised the government in its handling of the pandemic, said it was possible that Austria’s constitutional court could still stymie the vaccine mandate, especially if an “endemic” situation of the virus with low hospitalisation rates no longer makes vaccinations appear vital.Like many other European countries, Austria is experiencing record rates of Covid-19 infections, but the number of patients in intensive care beds with the virus is declining.With 68.8 per cent of its population having received at least two shots of a vaccine, however, the government argues that only mandatory vaccinations will bring immunisation rates to a sufficiently high level to weather another wave of the virus later this year.Last December’s emphatic endorsement of the vaccine mandate idea on behalf of the government, then still fronted by interim chancellor Alexander Schallenberg, has also made it politically difficult for the conservative Austrian People’s party to change its mind without losing face.“There’s a sense the whole of Europe is watching us: a government U-turn at this stage would amount to a huge loss of face,” said Clemens Schuhmann, a journalist for Oberösterreichische Nachrichten newspaper.Yet enforcing the mandate could come with the risk of further stoking isions in a society already polarised over the course of the pandemic.Upper Austria, the northern state that Schuhmann reports on, has one of the lowest vaccination rates in the country, with fewer than 60 per cent of residents fully vaccinated in some municipalities bordering on southern Germany.“Those who will get vaccinated because of the mandate are the ones who can’t afford to pay the fines”, he said. “The risk is that others will get further radicalised and rather go to prison than take the jab.”Everything you need to know about the Covid-19 outbreakStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: forty headless roman skeletons unearthed hs2 workers
story: Archaeologists working on the route of HS2 have uncovered dozens of decapitated Roman bodies, possible evidence of a mysterious religious cult widespread across Britain.The researchers, working to uncover buried secrets along the line of the new high-speed railway, found two large Roman burial grounds in Fleet Marston, outside Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire. Among the 425 or so bodies, there were 40 that had been decapitated post mortem and buried with their heads at their pelvis or their feet.While traditional theories suggest that such treatment was doled out only to criminals and outcasts, that was not the case at Fleet Marston, said Carl Champness, the project manager at Oxford Archaeology, one of a group of specialist companies working for HS2.“We don’t think it’s to do with criminals or outcasts because they are buried amongst the others, not always towards the edges or outskirts of the cemetery, and the same sort of care is given to their burial as everyone else,” Mr Champness told The .There was also an equal balance between male and female remains being treated in that manner, while in one case a young woman who appeared to have died in childbirth was decapitated and buried with her child.That particular interment may offer a hint as to what was taking place, according to Mr Champness.“Maybe the sudden death of a young person or an inidual for whatever reason, the unexpected nature of the death… that may be the reason we are seeing these decapitated iniduals,” he said.The appearance of such bodies in Roman burial sites in Britain is not unusual, Mr Champness explained, saying that a percentage of remains were often in such a state, suggesting that the cult was widespread at the time.Exactly what the beliefs behind the burial right were, however, remain a mystery.The cemeteries found at Fleet Marston are of ordinary people, rather than high-status iniduals, which adds to the intrigue, said Mr Champness.Unlike a villa mausoleum, these grounds contained “the everyday people who would have farmed the fields, manned the shops, the market stalls these are the people who actually were living in this area”.The archaeological dig is on the outskirts of a Roman trading town, which was about a days’ march from Verulamium near St Albans, and Alchester near Bicester.The wide clearings at the side of the road suggest that market stalls and gambling dens would have been set up there to cater for travellers and soldiers passing through.Signs of this commercial purpose include gaming dice, lead weights and more than 1,000 coins found during the excavations.More from News Russia-Ukraine crisis: Vladimir Putin praises Emmanuel Macron as leaders meet in MoscowMadagascar hit by second storm as title: foolish politicians have made life easy enemies west
story: Across Europe, including Britain, preening politicians took security for granted. Even as they cut defence spending, they stuck two fingers up to the United States, the ally upon whom European security depends. The European Union, which contributed to peace by integrating the economies of Western Europe, came to believe it had secured peace beyond France and Germany. It expanded its borders toward Russia, even opening talks with Ukraine, but lacks the hard power to defend its members and friends. Observing Russian aggression, Finland, an EU member state, now urgently seeks fast-tracked NATO membership and American protection.Everywhere we look the foolishness and naivety of the Complacent Generation is beginning to reveal itself. The examples are many, but the energy crisis especially is a case study in stupidity.The crisis may be international, but responsibility for Britain’s lack of preparedness lies at home. Energy prices have been rising here for years, thanks to ministers loading green surcharges onto household and industrial energy costs. Now, with rising Chinese demand for gas, Russia exploiting Europe’s dependence on its gas supplies, the post-pandemic resumption of the global economy, and Britain’s depleted gas storage capacity and refusal to exploit its own reserves, wholesale gas costs have more than quadrupled since before the pandemic. British households, and our energy-intensive industries, will pay the price, just as they will pay for rising inflation and, however necessary they might eventually be, tax rises. The whole structure of our economy – too reliant on financial services, too geographically unequal, too exposed to stretched supply chains, poorly connected, with low productivity and too little investment – is as it is because of the decisions and indecision of the Complacent Generation. No politician of any party has yet provided the coherent plan for growth we need.Neither is there a credible plan to project and defend Western interests as economic, diplomatic and military power shift eastward. Geopolitical change has been hastened by Western errors, like Middle Eastern wars, naivety, such as through world trade policies, and the virus, which disrupted democratic societies more than autocratic states. But Britain and our allies have also been blind – perhaps wilfully so – to the actions of our competitors and enemies.China has bought its way into our critical national infrastructure, our universities and even, as we learned recently, our democratic institutions. It has corrupted international institutions, from the World Health Organisation to Interpol. It has created rival organisations – such as the Asia Infrastructure Investment Bank – with the connivance of the British government. It has stolen industrial secrets and increased its economic and military reach around Asia and Africa.More from NewsChris Bryant accuses Boris Johnson of &#39inciting&#39 violence against Keir Starmer Russia-Ukraine crisis: Vladimir Putin praises Emmanuel Macron as leaders meet in MoscowMadagascar hit by second storm as Cyclone Batsirai displaces thousands and destroys critical cropsBritain sends 350 troops to Poland as Wallace warns Putin against &#39foolish mistake&#39Parents hit out at extra mock exams for overworked pupilsOttawa to arrest anyone bringing fuel to Covid &#39Freedom Convoy&#39 truckers after state of emergency declaredMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: rolls royce unveils smaller figurine aerodynamic pose bonnets
story: The Spirit of Ecstasy, the figurine that has sat on Rolls-Royce bonnets for the past 111 years, has shrunk.The car maker has unveiled a “reimagined” Spirit of Ecstasy for the electrical age. At 82.73mm tall, the new figure will be rolled out on Rolls-Royce’s first all electric car - the Spectre - when it goes on sale at the end of 2023. The streamlined Spirit has been slimmed down and remodelled to reduce drag, making the new car just that bit more aerodynamic.According to Rolls-Royce, the new figure is 17.28mm shorter than her predecessor (which measured 100.01mm).”Her robes, which flow behind her in the slipstream,” said the motoring company, “have been subtly reshaped to make them more aerodynamic and realistic.”But, said Rolls-Royce, “the most visible change is her stance”. The Spirit of Ecstasy had “previously stood with her feet together, legs straight and tilting at the waist.“Now, she is a true goddess of speed, braced for the wind, one leg forward, body tucked low, her eyes focused eagerly ahead”.After 830 hours of design modelling and wind tunnel testing, Rolls-Royce, based at Goodwood in West Sussex, but now a subsidiary of BMW, is delighted with the result. Not everybody else is quite so keen. The ’s motoring correspondent Jeremy Taylor concluded: “We think it’s, well, likely to be isive, looking as though it’s been attacked with a flamethrower.“Close inspection reveals that instead of leaning forward from the waist as previously, the woman is now crouched on bended knee. A subtle change that some might say amounts to diddly squat, literally.”Many  readers appeared to agree with him. “Unbelievable on so many levels. Aerodynamic drag on a 3 sculpture? Changing a well respected, traditional, lovely mascot? Ludicrous waste of time,” posted Phil Carmichael.Steve Webb wrote: “Unfortunately the picture I first saw made it look like a lady about to undergo a Gynaecology examination! Dear RR please leave well alone.”Rolls-Royce Motor Cars said the only mutterings of discontent had been emanating from the ’s correspondent. Out of hundreds of articles written about the design change, this was the only negative one.This is not the first time the Spirit of Ecstasy has enjoyed a revamp. In the car maker’s 111 -year history, the mascot has been altered subtly or otherwise around 12 times. This is the smallest version yet and while it reduces aerodynamic drag, it also helps when it has to shrink back into the bonnet on collision. The smaller, presumably the easier, the Spirit of Ecstasy is to retract.A Rolls-Royce spokesman said it had made the Spirit retractable in case of collisions. Legislation in certain countries - largely in the European Union - has ruled the figurine a danger to pedestrians. Not that that had ever been an issue, the spokesman said.  It also prevents the figure being stolen by passing thieves.The original Spirit of Ecstasy was designed by Charles Sykes – an artist and sculptor. Originally called The Whisper, the first Spirit of Ecstasy was based on a bronze sculpture Sykes had previously created for Lord Montagu of Beaulieu’s car and which in turn was based on Eleanor Thornton, the aristocrat’s lover.   More from News Russia-Ukraine crisis: Vladimir Putin praises Emmanuel Macron as leaders meet in MoscowMadagascar hit by second storm as Cyclone Batsirai displaces thousands and destroys critical cropsBritain sends 350 troops to Poland as Wallace warns Putin against &#39foolish mistake&#39Parents hit out at extra mock exams for overworked pupilsOttawa to arrest anyone bringing fuel to Covid &#39Freedom Convoy&#39 truckers after state of emergency declaredThe Crown star Claire Foy ‘was sent emails threatening rape by stalker who turned up at her home’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: inflation rishi sunak cant just hide behind bank england
story: Inflation is headed above 7 per cent, according to the Bank of England. So what does the Government intend to do about it? Often, when this question is asked, the response is: “Surely controlling inflation is the Bank of England’s job? Nothing to do with the Government.” That’s wrong, and it’s important to understand why.The Bank of England has what economists call “operational independence” over monetary policy. That means the Bank sets interest rates rather than, as in former times, the Chancellor of the Exchequer. But that doesn’t mean that inflation has nothing to do with the Government.First, it is the Government's job to tell the Bank of England what inflation rate it should be seeking to target each year. Presumably the answer for 2022 isn’t 2 per cent, unless the Chancellor is hoping the Bank will raise rates extremely aggressively in the next month or two. So if it isn’t 2 per cent, what is it?The response from some is to insist that the target ought to be 2 per cent even if that isn’t what’s wanted this year. That makes no sense. The Chancellor sets this annual target, so what does he want it to be this year? If he doesn’t care what it is this year, he can say that, but it is his job to set the target.Next, the Chancellor decides how far above the target it is acceptable for inflation to go in the short-term and what the consequences are for the Bank if the target is missed. So how far above is ok, assuming inflation would eventually fall back to target? Clearly, being  more than 5 percent above seems to be acceptable. Would being 10 per cent above be fine? Or 20 per cent? What discretion is the Chancellor allowing for the Bank? Is that just unlimited? If so, why is its being unlimited the right policy?The Bank has operational independence regarding the execution of monetary policy. But monetary policy isn't the only thing that affects inflation. Other policies do as well – for instance, the level of the Budget deficit. Will the Government seek to reinforce anti-inflationary monetary policy (by tightening the deficit) or to mitigate its effects (by loosening the deficit)?And it isn’t just the deficit. The Bank of England Governor has suggested that people should not seek wage rises in response to inflation. Such second-round effects can make inflation more persistent and the cost of cutting it higher. So does the Government intend to bolster the Governor's stance by limiting public sector pay rises this year?One of the concerns economists expressed about the switch to Bank of England independence was that it might risk people coming to think that controlling inflation was not the Government’s responsibility. Now matters may be even worse than that, for governments may succumb to the temptation to do more inflationary things in a futile short-term attempt to offset the political costs of inflation. We see some of that in response to soaring energy prices. The Government has announced a subsidy to energy bills to offset the impact of energy-price inflation on households. But governments cannot make inflation go away by just spending extra money. Everyone has known that for over 45 years, since the misguided attempts in the 1970s to “outgrow inflation” in the Barber Boom.If the government wants to get inflation down and to do so without unnecessarily high costs in terms of unemployment and output, it needs the right blend of policies. These may include properly enforced annual inflation targets to manage expectations of workers and firms, so they do not raise wages and prices too rapidly in response to future inflation movements changing deficit targets to reflect inflationary pressures, and public sector pay rises reflective of inflation targets (insofar as they are credible). That is the right way to go. Not subsidies to wish away specific price increases. Hold the Government to account for inflation and give it political credit when inflation is kept under control. Don’t let it pretend that controlling inflation is someone else’s job.More from NewsBoris Johnson sang ‘I Will Survive’, says new communications chief Guto Harri Russia-Ukraine crisis: Vladimir Putin praises Emmanuel Macron as leaders meet in MoscowChris Bryant accuses Boris Johnson of &#39inciting&#39 violence against Keir StarmerMadagascar hit by second storm as Cyclone Batsirai displaces thousands and destroys critical cropsBritain sends 350 troops to Poland as Wallace warns Putin against &#39foolish mistake&#39Parents hit out at extra mock exams for overworked pupilsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: paraplegic man walks thanks electronic implant spine
story: A completely paralysed man was able to walk again at the touch of a button after an electronic implant was placed in his spine in a groundbreaking operation.Italian Michel Roccati had no movement or feeling in his legs following a motorcycle accident in 2017 which severed the nerves in his spinal cord.However, after Swiss researchers implanted an electronic array, which stimulates the nerves below the injury, he was instantly able to stand and walk, and has since been able to cycle and swim.“The first few steps were incredible – a dream come true. It was very emotional to see my legs moving,” said the 30-year-old.“I’ve been through some pretty intense training in the past few months, and I’ve set myself a series of goals. For instance, I can now go up and down stairs, and I hope to be able to walk one kilometre by this spring.”Similar technology has been used to help patients with partial paralysis, but it is the first time it has been shown to work in people who had no movement at all.The implant was developed by scientists at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (EPFL) and Lausanne University Hospital, and works by stimulating the region of the spinal cord that activates specific muscle groups in the trunk and legs.The team needs at least six centimetres (2.4 inches) of healthy spinal cord below the injury so that the implant can stimulate certain nerves. It is fitted underneath the vertebrae, inside the spinal column. They then use artificial intelligence to discover the sequence of neurons which fire in iniduals when they want to carry out various activities, such as walking, cycling and even canoeing.At the moment, the implant uses just 16 electrodes to stimulate the nerves, but in time, the researchers want to move to 32 or 64 to gain even greater control.After the implant, patients need about 10 days of recovery, before the implant can be switched on. As well as Mr Roccati, it has been also trialled successfully on three other patients.Prof Gregoire Courtine, a neuroscientist from EPFL, said: “Our stimulation algorithms are based on imitating nature, and work exactly in the way that the spinal cord is stimulated by the brain. “When you first turn it on you can stand, and step but you still need support, and the gait pattern is poor, but it allows you to start training all this activity immediately, and over the course of several months we can decrease the support.“All three patients were able to stand, walk, pedal, swim and control their torso movements in just one day, after their implants were activated. That’s thanks to the specific stimulation programs we wrote for each type of activity.“We are not yet at the stage where it’s a commercially available technology that you can use with your smartphone, but that’s our next objective.”For Mr Roccati’s first attempt, two small remote controls were attached to a walker to help him support himself because years of inactivity meant his muscles were severely wasted. The remote controls were attached wirelessly to a tablet which forwards the correct signals to a pacemaker in his abdomen. That pacemaker then relays the signals to the implant which stimulates specific neurons in a specific sequence, allowing the muscles to fire up in the correct order.Mr Roccati underwent surgery for the implant last August and has been steadily improving ever since.He said: “I had an accident on a motorbike and I immediately understood there was something wrong. I tried to move my legs and saw it was impossible. But I fixed in my mind that it was a problem to be solved.“I was living with my parents, and now I have an apartment and I can do everything alone no problem.”Dr Jocelyne Bloch, a neurosurgeon at Lausanne University Hospital, added: “There are so many patients around the world who need a treatment to fight against paralysis.“This technology is so precise that immediately after the surgery, the patient can walk and stand. The electrodes are arranged in a way that corresponds exactly to the spinal nerve roots.“That gives us precise control over the neurons regulating specific muscles. Ultimately, it allows for greater selectivity and accuracy in controlling the motor sequences for a given activity.”While the progress achievable in a single day is groundbreaking, the gains after several months are even more impressive.The three patients were able to regain muscle mass, move around more independently, and take part in social activities like having a drink standing at a bar.The team is now working with Onward Medical, a medical technology company, to move the technology to a smartphone, so patients can simply select the activity they need.Larger clinical trials will be taking place in the US and Europe imminently, with the team hoping the device will be available within the next two to three years.Details of the research were published in the journal Nature Medicine.More from News Russia-Ukraine crisis: Vladimir Putin praises Emmanuel Macron as leaders meet in MoscowMadagascar hit by second storm as Cyclone Batsirai displaces thousands and destroys critical cropsBritain sends 350 troops to Poland as Wallace warns Putin against &#39foolish mistake&#39Parents hit out at extra mock exams for overworked pupilsOttawa to arrest anyone bringing fuel to Covid &#39Freedom Convoy&#39 truckers after state of emergency declaredThe Crown star Claire Foy ‘was sent emails threatening rape by stalker who turned up at her home’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: putins global goals
story: The Russians have continued to build up their forces around Ukraine US officials fear they could take Kyiv within two days. Some observers believe the West should stay out of Vladimir Putin’s “backyard” – a handful of American conservatives even admire the way he runs his country – but this flash of isolationism is not realism. It is utterly misguided.Mr Putin’s claim that Russia and Ukraine are an inisible part of ancient Rus is fantasy. Ukraine is an independent nation, the security of which several nations, including the UK and Russia, vowed to respect in a 1994 treaty. Nato membership for Kyiv is not on the table (the Ukrainian enthusiasm for it has only increased in reaction to Moscow’s interference).Moreover, Mr Putin’s goals are global. He muscled his way into Syria. He has attempted to interfere in the democratic process in the West. And his celebrity appearance at the Winter Olympics in Beijing underscored the global stakes of this stand-off. China is watching how we handle Russia.If the West tolerates the invasion of a democratic friend, Beijing is far more likely to risk a campaign against Taiwan – just as it has already eroded democracy in Hong Kong and persecuted its Uighur population.More from News Russia-Ukraine crisis: Vladimir Putin praises Emmanuel Macron as leaders meet in MoscowMadagascar hit by second storm as Cyclone Batsirai displaces thousands and destroys critical cropsBritain sends 350 troops to Poland as Wallace warns Putin against &#39foolish mistake&#39Parents hit out at extra mock exams for overworked pupilsOttawa to arrest anyone bringing fuel to Covid &#39Freedom Convoy&#39 truckers after state of emergency declaredThe Crown star Claire Foy ‘was sent emails threatening rape by stalker who turned up at her home’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: sajid javid calls public cancel jimmy carr horrid holocaust
story: Comedy fans should boycott Jimmy Carr’s Netflix show over his Holocaust joke, Sajid Javid has said, urging people to send a “strong message” about unacceptable speech.Carr has found himself at the centre of controversy after a clip from his recent Netflix special, His Dark Material, was shared widely on social media.“When people talk about the Holocaust, they talk about the tragedy of six million lives being lost to the Nazi war machine. But they never mention the thousands of gipsies killed by the Nazis, because no-one wants to talk about the positives,” he said, to audience laughter.Mr Javid, the Health Secretary, described the joke as “horrid” and told Times Radio: “I think we all have a right to react to that, and one of the best ways anyone can react to that is to show these platforms what they think about Jimmy Carr by not watching or listening to him, and that will send him a very strong message.”The Prime Minister’s official spokesman said of Carr’s joke: “Those comments are deeply disturbing, and its unacceptable to make light of genocide.”Asked whether Netflix should pull the show, the spokesman said: “That will be a matter for them. We are clear that mocking the atrocities of the Holocaust is unacceptable.” He added that the Government was “toughening measures for social media and streaming platforms who don’t tackle harmful content” and “making sure that streaming services are more accountable”.Netflix made no comment on the matter.Carr issued a “trigger warning” to the audience at the beginning of the show, telling viewers he would say “terrible things”.His joke was condemned by the Holocaust Memorial Day Trust and the Auschwitz Memorial. The Traveller Movement, a charity supporting the traveller community in the UK, launched a petition calling for Netflix to remove the “truly disturbing” segment.David Baddiel, the comedian, tweeted: “Jimmy is a close friend of mine and a brilliant stand-up in general. Makes no difference to how I feel or think about this specific joke.”He said: “You can obviously tell a Holocaust joke that is cruel and inhumane and mean-spirited and racist. Or you can tell one that targets the oppressors, or draws attention to the fundamental evil of it, or shines a light on the humanity of the victims. Clearly, Jimmy Carr’s was the former.”Those defending Carr included Victoria Coren Mitchell, host of BBC Two’s Only Connect and a  columnist, who said she would not have made the joke but described him as “a man full of goodness and kindness… a properly decent person”.According to The Mirror, Carr addressed the controversy during a performance at the Whitley Bay Playhouse on Saturday night. Discussing cancel culture, he said: “The joke that ends my career is already out there.”This is not the first time has stood firm against calls to remove or censure a comedian on its site. Dave Chappelle, a US comedian, sparked a backlash when he made remarks about the transgender community in his Netflix special The Closer.Ted Sarandos, the service’s chief content officer, said he did not believe the comments passed the threshold for hate speech.More from NewsMadagascar hit by second storm as Cyclone Batsirai displaces thousands and destroys critical cropsBritain sends 350 troops to Poland as Wallace warns Putin against &#39foolish mistake&#39 Russia-Ukraine crisis: Putin praises Macron following meeting in MoscowParents hit out at extra mock exams for overworked pupilsOttawa to arrest anyone bringing fuel to Covid &#39Freedom Convoy&#39 truckers after state of emergency declaredThe Crown star Claire Foy ‘was sent emails threatening rape by stalker who turned up at her home’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: unique shorthand created charles dickens finally deciphered
story: Charles Dickens’s unique shorthand was so impenetrable that the author himself dubbed it “the devil’s handwriting”.Now, 210 years after his birth, researchers have deciphered its mysteries - and in doing so, uncovered an angry dispute with a newspaper over a blocked advertisement.The celebrated Victorian learnt Gurney’s shorthand at an early age, but modified it to create his own unique system that scholars had found all but unbreakable.Gurney’s shorthand was devised in the mid-18th century by Thomas Gurney, who published it under the title “Brachygraphy, or Swift Writing, Made easy to Meanest Capacity”. Dickens learnt it in his spare time and later used the skill to become a freelance reporter.Now, a team of researchers, backed by amateur enthusiasts, claim to have deciphered more than half of his private code, unlocking at least one letter and potentially nine other documents.The May 1859 missive, one of 10 known documents in Dickens's own hand that, until now, have been impossible to read, is addressed to the then-editor of The Times, JT Delane.The creator of Oliver Twist wanted to promote a new literary journal in an advertisement placed in the newspaper.At the time, Dickens already co-owned a journal, Household Words, with his publishers, Bradbury &amp Evans.However, after falling out with them over a perceived lack of support during his separation from his wife Catherine, Dickens went to court to seek the journal's dissolution.He subsequently founded a new journal, All the Year Round, and aiming to draw in former Household Words readers, sought to place an advertisement in The Times that claimed the latter journal had been discontinued by him.Fearing legal repercussions, a clerk at the paper rejected Dickens’s submission, much to the author’s fury.In his letter to Mr Delane, a shorthand copy of which he kept, possibly for legal reasons, the 19th Century novelist claimed he had used precisely the form of words that the Master of the Rolls had ordered him to use in the court ruling.Dr Claire Wood, a lecturer in Victorian literature at the University of Leicester and part of the Dickens Code team that cracked the hieroglyphic handwriting, told The  that they had now deciphered around 60 per cent of Dickens’s shorthand.The project has brought together academic authorities on Dickens, experts in applied linguistics and amateur code-breakers from around the world.A £300 reward was offered for the most complete attempt to decode the letter. The overall winner was Shane Braggs, from California, who said he discovered the puzzle while browsing code groups on the social media site Reddit.So far, only 60-70 per cent of the letter has been translated, but it is enough to uncover its meaning.Describing the process of cracking the code, Hugo Bowles, a professor at the University of Foggia and author of Dickens and the Stenographic Mind, said: “We collected the lightbulb flashes from different solvers and everything just fitted together. You might call it ‘jigsaw reading’. One of our solvers found the words ‘Ascension Day’ and another found ‘next week’, which helped us pinpoint the date of the letter. Solvers who knew their Dickens identified the abbreviation ‘HW’ as his journal Household Words and connected the symbol for ‘round’ to his journal All the Year Round.With at least 40 per cent of the shorthand still to be cracked, the project will continue until 2023, with monthly challenges to get the public involved.“The great thing about working on it as a kind of crowdsourced initiative is that with every symbol that is decoded, we're building a glossary,” Dr Wood said. “So with every kind of step forward that we make, it becomes more and more likely that we'll be able to to make real progress in the undeciphered manuscripts.”More from News Russia-Ukraine crisis: Vladimir Putin praises Emmanuel Macron as leaders meet in MoscowMadagascar hit by second storm as Cyclone Batsirai displaces thousands and destroys critical cropsBritain sends 350 troops to Poland as Wallace warns Putin against &#39foolish mistake&#39Parents hit out at extra mock exams for overworked pupilsOttawa to arrest anyone bringing fuel to Covid &#39Freedom Convoy&#39 truckers after state of emergency declaredThe Crown star Claire Foy ‘was sent emails threatening rape by stalker who turned up at her home’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: 12000 dwp work coaches biggest
story: Exclusive: , DWP work coaches in biggest ever Jobs Army told to reapply for their own jobsThousands of Universal Credit advisors who were hired to form Britain’s biggest ever Jobs Army are now having to reapply for their jobs - with one telling the Mirror they are “let down” and “blindsided”Work coaches are employed in hundreds of Jobcentres across the countryByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA staggering , Universal Credit advisors who were hired to create Britain’s “biggest ever Jobs Army” have been told to reapply for their own jobs. Department for Work and Pensionschiefs wrote to thousands of Work Coaches last week offering them an “opportunity to apply for a permanent role”.The number of Work Coaches doubled from , to , during the Covid pandemic as Universal Credit claims surged. But many are on fixed-term contracts, and senior officials admit some face being let go when those deals end in June. An e-mail seen by the Mirror told staff: “We hope you will decide to continue your career with DWP and apply for this opportunity.” So many are hit that virtual sessions - which have a limit of , participants - were split into alphabetical groups by surname.  One work coach - whose role involves sitting in Jobcentres across Britain helping claimants into jobs - said they felt “let down” and “blindsided”. They told the Mirror: “Some managers have suggested those affected should feel aposluckyapos to have this opportunity. “They have said they will try and keep aposthe majorityapos but nothing more specic than that.” The job fears mainly affect ‘EO’ grade Work Coaches. Union chiefs said in December that “nearly all” the , ‘AO’ grade coaches would stay. DWP Permanent Secretary Peter Schofield suggested last year that the total of , work coaches could fall by thousands, to “well above ,. He said the number would “fall away” because fewer people were in the most intensive work search groups on Universal Credit.  Yet it comes days after Tory ministers announced a ‘Way to Work’ target, to move , Universal Credit claimants into work by June. Claimants will be forced to take jobs that aren’t in their specialist area four weeks after making a claim, or have their benefits stopped. The DWP confirmed , fixed-term work coaches have been told to reapplythey want permanent jobs.  Final decisions are expected in mid-March. A DWP spokesperson said: “We recognise the important contribution our staff on fixed-term contracts have made over the pandemic period and expect to be able to offer permanent roles to the majority of those, as we continue to deliver our multi-billion pound Plan for Jobs.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON JobcentresConservative PartyDepartment for Work and PensionsPublic servicesPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: boris rishi need good neighbours
story: Neighbours, everybody needs good neighbours... but the Boris and Rishi fairytale is going to end in tearsDowning Street has found the perfect blend of bluster and billionaire, says Fleet Street Fox. But how long will Errorsboroughs marriage of convenience last Its the wedding of Rot and Brylcreem - a match made in hellopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsIf thereaposs one thing that Boris Johnson is disciplined about, itaposs control. Specically, not being subject to it. Wedding vows, lockdown rules, basic morality, the Ministerial Code, his own manesto: the default response of the Prime Minister to all of them is PAH! Which is why itaposs interesting that, a week after the worst week in his premiership since the previous worst week, which was only the week before, the PM is now submitting himself to the control of his Chancellor of the Exchequer.In a single weekend, Rishi Sunakaposs mates have moved into No, expensive policy announcements have been binned, and the crime of fraud which has taken £bn off the taxpayer on Covid alone has been downgraded to a harmless infraction of little consequence.  Unfortunately, this whirlwind romance is headed for some very big and pointy rocks.The first is that the cost of living crisis, which is already a crisis, is going to get worse with food costs predicted by millionaires to rise another % in April. No-one knows what to call something worse than a crisis, but the dictionary will probably need updating to include something like crisaster.The second is the energy crisis, in which the taxpayer has been forced to compensate corporate giants for not being able to steal money immediately, and instead letting them steal it over  years. Prices are likely to rise again in the autumn, and because  months was too long for billion-pound firms to wait, the government may allow an extra price rise in the summer to tide them over. Presumably, weaposll be calling this frobbery.If Boris thinks Her Upstairs is dficult to live with, heaposs going to flip when he finds out that Rishi is the sort of spouse whoaposll give him £ towards the housekeeping, and then ask for £ back by exerting some below-inflation fiscal drag on state pensions. On the face of it, their relationship is rooted in shared politics and a mutual love of money. But while one partner is a hedge funder whoaposs got more money than the Queen, the other never carries cash because he canapost hold onto it for more than  minutes.Both of them seem unable to spot a party when it involves  people, soft drinks, beer, renditions of Happy Birthday, a society wallpaperer, an official photographer, a strategically-sly cake, and a police investigation. Both, according to reports, are also capable of enjoying all that in the space of just  minutes before getting on with the job, which is a polite way of saying you burped all afternoon.But thereaposs little  these two have in common. One is a spender, the other a spaffer. One drinks beer, the other power. One is vain enough to arrange photocalls on staircases so he doesnapost look as short, while the other has just one suit and no comb. Read moreToday, weaposre told that a major announcement on Borisapos big promise to use the £bn National Insurance increase to bring down NHS waiting lists has been boiled down to a website, so that you can stop ringing the doctor to find out about your appointment and just throw the computer out of the window instead.Officially, the plan isnapost ready yet, and unofficially Rishiaposs blocking it until heaposs PM and can announce it himself. And therein lies the problem with this partnership: only last week, Johnsonaposs friends were telling him to kick Sunak out, on the grounds he was trying to steal his job.Imagine a bride trying to get the groom sacked, withholding cash while giving it to rich mates, giving Princess Diana eyes in TV interviews whenever sheaposs asked about parties. Picture a groom so desperate to keep the house that heaposll overlook their dferences, let her take total control, and start measuring up for curtains he will never get to see.Think about a relationship in that much trouble before its second anniversary. It might work in an Australian daytime soap, but it ainapost going to last in a world where people donapost come back from the dead after  years lost at sea. Johnson thinks heaposs saved his skin by ceding control to his most ambitious enemy, and boasts it would now take a Panzer ision to get him out of No. Sunak, meanwhile, is quietly lining up his tanks in the Downing Street garden, which he has always had a great view of from his No office. The PM is being infantilised by enemies saying his we wields all the power, and potentially criminalised by his friends claiming that she has nothing to do with his work, but nevertheless attended a lot of work events.And the only PR expert who can be persuaded to enter the fray is someone who considers the PM sexually incontinent, throws Benny Hill salutes at world leaders, quotes Gloria Gaynor, and on his first day gives the press the headline: Heaposs not a COMPLETE clown. But the fundamental flaw with this great reset, which is probably more of a breather to allow Rishi to liquidate assets, is that it involves trying to instil discipline in a man who has spent a letime shucking it. The fact he needs to be taught the self-control of a toddler is why he lives in Errorsborough - a town twinned with Débâcle.Fans may think these two have found the perfect blend of bluster and billionaire, but itaposll last only as long as it takes for Johnson to take back being out-of-control, and Sunak deciding that his tanks are ready to evict. title: expat tells tories pay up
story: Expat tells Tories to pay up after pension frozen at £ a week for  yearsBrian Green, , from Billinge, Merseyside, emigrated to Australia in  meaning his UK state pension was frozen at £ a week and hes never benefited from the yearly increases others getBrian Green, , is furious as his state pension is ‘frozen’ at £ per week Image: End Frozen Pensions YouTubeByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Feb |comments An expat retiree has told the Government to pay up after his state pension was frozen at £-a-week for  years.Brian Green is among an estimated half a million Brits living abroad whose pension payments no longer increase at the normal rate.The -year-old, originally from Billinge near Wigan, Lancashire, moved to Queensland, Australia, with his we in  to be closer to the coupleaposs daughters, reports the . The majority of British nationals see their pension go up yearly as high as . percent, in line with average earnings or inflation under the triple lock. Even though this policy has been temporarily suspended, most will be expecting a rise this year. The Government says increases are only guaranteed for those living in the UK, the European Economic Area , Gibraltar, Switzerland and countries with a social security agreement with the UK . Mr Green and his we - who did not wish to be named - were born and lived in the UK all their lives before emigrating. Speaking to the End Frozen Pensions campaign, the pensioner said: Our pensions have been frozen for some  years. I receive £., and my we receives £..Are you affected by a pension freeze  Let us know at webnews@mirror This, I believe, is immoral. If we had chosen to live in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo or Turkey, or indeed  other countries with which the UK has a bilateral or reciprocal arrangement, our pensions would not have been frozen. Mr Green appeared to accept the idea the UK Government will not pay backdated pensions to impacted expats across the globe. However, he added: But they could start paying the full and entitled pensions from now. Today. Since leaving their home shores, Mr Green and his we have ed annually for two months. But Mr Green highlighted their pensions undergo a temporary change when they reach Britain. He continued: “During that stay, we received an increased entitlement to our pensions.  “So on Monday, when I set off, my pension is frozen in Australia. On Tuesday, when I arrive, my pension is thawed. “What does it matter where I am ” Mr Green is keen to highlight the issue which is thought to affect hundreds of thousands of people across the world. He concluded by urging the government to take action, and said: “I paraphrase the words from Sir Henry Newbolt’s splendid poem: Vitai Lampada. “Government - pay up! Pay up! And play the game.” A DWP spokesperson previously said: “We understand that people move abroad for many reasons and that this can impact on their finances. “There is information on GOV.UK about what the effect of going abroad will be on entitlement to the UK state pension. “The Government’s policy on the up-rating of the UK state pension for recipients living overseas is a longstanding one of more than  years and we continue to uprate state pensions overseas where there is a legal requirement to do so.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Department for Work and PensionsFrozenState pension" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: how 2022 gcses levels different
story: How will  GCSEs and A Levels be dferent and will exams take place in person School pupils have had to bear the brunt of huge changes in the education system over the pandemic. As post-Covid adjustments continue, they will have to adapt again as GCSE and A-Level changes are unveiledThe UKs exam halls have sat largely empty over the past couple of years Image: PAByHarry ThompsonTrends Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments National GCSE and A-Level exams are due to undergo major changes this year, in an effort to help children affected by years of Covid-affected schooling. Those in education have had one of the most disrupted rides through the pandemic, with traditions and institutions normally a consistent and unchanging part of being young all going out of the window with the arrival of coronavirus. Now though, following the governmentaposs plans to ease the nation out of the grip of Covid amid the recession of the Omicron wave, efforts are being made tothe school experience back to something more like the pre-pandemic UK.Naturally, though, the move to the aposnew normalapos will require efforts and guidance to help the transition, for the generation forced to live through the changes, as smooth and fair experiences as possible. Will GCSE and A-Level exams be held in    The first, and perhaps most signicant, change to exam structure this year will be that GCSE and A-Level exams themselves will once again be going ahead. In  and , would-be exam sitters were instead given their results based on assessments made by their teachers, rather than the more traditional format of people flocking into exam halls to attempt papers under controlled conditions. The pandemic-specic format of handing out grades, rather than sitting exams, was introduced to prevent school children from spreading Covid amongst themselves by attending the exam in person. It was also due to the immense disruption caused by the pandemic, which led to children missing schoolthey tested positive, classes being online-only and teacher absences due to positive Covid tests. Grade boundaries will be lower with more generous grading  Ofsted, Englandaposs exams regulator, has said that grade boundaries are likely to be lower this year than they have been in the past. This means that papers are likely to be given more generous grades than they have been in previous years. The more lenient grade boundaries, which are due to come into play for children in Wales, Scotland and England, will aim to help soften the transition for children once again securing qualications through the normal exam method.The BBC report that there will be a aposmid-pointapos between the grade boundaries, seen in pre- years and throughout the pandemic and teacher assessment era.Dr Jo Saxton, the Ofsted chief regulator, said the aim was to give children a safety net when tackling a transitional period for the exams system. GCSE and A-Level students will be getting advanced information  Teenagers set to take exams this year will now be able to get information on what will be inside the paper ahead of time. News of the change appeared on the websites of exam boards on Febuary , , and it is set to cover over  formats across a range of exam levels from A-Level, AS and GCSE. The advanced information will aim to help children focus their revision, although it is reportedly unlikely to reduce the amount of content exam-takers will need to get their heads around.Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said: “Exams are the best and fairest form of assessment, and we firmly intend for them to take place this summer, giving students a fair chance to show what they know.“We know students have faced challenges during the pandemic, which is why we’ve put fairness for them at the forefront of our plans. “The information to help with their revision published today, as well as the range of other adaptations, will make sure they can do themselves justice in their exams this summer.” In a statement regarding the extra information, the Department for Education said it: “Aims to focus students’ revision without providing exact questions that will appear”. It added: “Advanced sight of the content is one part of the adaptations in place to help mitigate the impact of the pandemic on education, recognising this cohort of students were affected by school closures during periods of lockdown and disruption due to absences. “Other adaptations include a choice of topics in some GCSEs like English literature and history, and support materials like formulae sheets in maths.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON EducationExamsNadhim ZahawiGCSEsA-levelsState exams" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: plan gcses level exams 2022
story: Plan for GCSEs and A-level exams  unveiled as students get extra revision helpExam boards have published details of the topics that will come up in papers, and students for GCSEs, AS and A-levels will have extra revision help from today as ministers insist theyll go aheadPupils have faced huge disruption to learning because of Covid Image: PAByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsChildren studying for GCSEs, AS and A-levels this summer will have extra revision help from today as ministers insist exams will go ahead. Examiners will also be asked to be more generous than in previous years to account for the disruptions to education triggered by the pandemic. Pupils have suffered a third academic year of Covid-fuelled chaos to their schooling.But ministers pledged boosted support for youngsters so they are not unfairly penalised by the Covid- crisis.Some content, texts, topics and sub-topics, themes and skills due to be assessed have been made available for the majority of GCSE, AS and A-level subjects, including maths, biology, chemistry and languages. Exam boards today published the details of topics that will appear in exams as part of changes to ease the pandemicaposs impact on grades.  The advance information is aimed at cutting the amount of content pupils need to be taught or tested on. In all subjects apart from English literature, history, ancient history, geography and art and design, pupils will be given notice about the topics to be covered in this summeraposs exams. The Department for Education said the extra information “aims to focus students’ revision without providing exact questions that will appear”. It added: “Advanced sight of the content is one part of the adaptations in place to help mitigate the impact of the pandemic on education, recognising this cohort of students were affected by school closures during periods of lockdown and disruption due to absences. “Other adaptations include a choice of topics in some GCSEs like English literature and history, and support materials like formulae sheets in maths.” Jo Saxton, chief regulator of exams watchdog Ofqual, said: “Students have shown so much resilience during the pandemic and we know that they are seeking certainty. “Advance information published today is one of the ways we are supporting students to have that certainty as they prepare to show what they know and can do. “We are also ensuring there is a safety-net for students with a generous approach to grading.” Association of School and College Leaders general secretary Geoff Barton said: It is extremely important that this really does help to mitigate the impact of the pandemic on learning, and we will be studying it in detail to ensure that it provides fairness to students of all ability levels. National Education Union joint general secretary Mary Bousted feared the release of advance information “comes too late” for kids. “There are grave concerns amongst teachers of exam groups that this will not be enough to fairly mitigate the disruption these students have experienced over two academic years,” she added. Shadow Schools Minister Stephen Morgan claimed children and teachers “have had weeks of needless stress and uncertainty awaiting the information being published today, which for many pupils will feel like scant compensation for months of missed learning and development”.  An Ofqual spokesman confirmed there will “be generous grading” this year. He added: This will be delivered after marking is complete and when senior examiners set grade boundaries. “It is likely to mean grade boundaries will be a little lower than they might have been in a normal year, but grade boundaries are never set in advance, and so we cannot be precise at this point in the year.Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said exams ”are the best and fairest form of assessment, and we firmly intend for them to take place this summer, giving students a fair chance to show what they know”.He added: “We know students have faced challenges during the pandemic, which is why we’ve put fairness for them at the forefront of our plans. “The information to help with their revision published today, as well as the range of other adaptations, will make sure they can do themselves justice in their exams this summer.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON EducationSchoolsGCSEsA-levels" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Autistic teen who stayed home for  years due to anxiety stabbed on second outingBilly Baxter, , from Blackburn, needed le-saving surgery after being kned in the heart and lungs and now has a -inch scar running down theof his chestBilly Baxter, , was kned in the heart and lungs Image: Jessie Brian   SWNSByTom EarnshawTanveer MannDeputy News Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsAn autistic teen who stayed inside his home for over  years due to social anxiety was brutally stabbed while venturing out for just the second time. Billy Baxter, , from Blackburn, was kned in the heart and lungs on the evening of September  last year while walking near his home in what is believed to be a row over a girl. He had to undergo le-saving surgery after the attack and has since been left with a -inch scar running down theof his chest. His mum Jessie Brian, , found out about the attack when Billy messaged her on Snapchat to say he was on his way to hospital. She said the teen had been left traumatised by the incident and the family now plans to move out of the area. His  year-old attacker - who cannot be named for legal reasons - was sentenced to just  months in custody for the offence last week.  He was originally charged with attempted murder but this was downgraded to wounding with intent by the Crown Prosecution Service. Jessie hit out at the sentence, calling it a slap on the wrist while Billy had been forced to turn his back on his le and ambitions. Billy wanted to be a plumber and now heaposs too scared to go out of the house just when he got his confidence back, she said. Itaposs heart-breaking what heaposs done to my son, and in court, he held his head up high like nothing had happened. Iaposve been around this area for  years - itaposs the only area that Iaposve known - and now we have to leave because the attacker knows my address and so does his family. Billy has ADHD and autism and had spent more than two years without leaving his girlfriendaposs house due to his lelong developmental disability. But they broke up shortly before the attack on September  last year and Billy moved back home with Jessie. He was ambushed after leaving the house at around .pm to meet up with a new love interest. Jessie said: Heaposd been in a relationship, and heaposd found out she was cheating on him, so he came back home after isolating with her for two and a half years.  I said to Billy, Just get out there! You need to start socialising with people and making new friends. Forget about everything thataposs happened. So heaposd met this young girl, and managed to get to town and to see her, but then he heard his name being shouted across the road. He put his hood down and didnapost want any trouble, but next thing he knew the lad was in front of his face, and he got stabbed straight in the chest. Jessie said she found out about the stabbing after Billy contacted her over messaging  Snapchat in the minutes after it took place. She said: I got a phone call from one of his friends on Snapchat, and it was actually Billy on the phone saying that he had been stabbed. I thought it was someone having a joke because it didnapost sound like Billy. It was only when he said: It is me, mum, Iaposve been stabbed and Iaposm on my way to the hospital, thataposs when I found out. Billy was rushed to hospital where he required a le-saving operation after doctors found out he had internal bleeding. Jessie said: He was stabbed in the chest, between his heart and his liver. They had to open him up and pull his rib cage back and do an operation on his heart, and they had to repair the tube as well. It was an operation that he had to have within  hours - a le-saving operation - because he had internal bleeding as well, which is very, very dangerous. She added: It was a nightmare to tell you the truth, it really was a nightmare. Billy was left with a huge scar running down his chest, along with a couple of smaller ones dotted just above his stomach. But Jessie said that the poor lad was also left with mental trauma, which continues to this day. She said: My -year-old who wanted to go to college and be a plumber hasnapost got a le now because he wonapost go out. He feels very conscious about the scars. He talks about it every single day. Itaposs not just one little scar. Itaposs one big massive scar and two scars underneath it. Jessie also feels the sentence that her sonaposs attacker received wonapost deter other kids from carrying knives in the future. She said:  months is a slap on the hand. This boy who did all this will probably get out and get a job or whatever, and my son is left not knowing what to do next. story: Happy dog with dferent tie for each day of the week ‘makes every person that crosses his path smile’Australian shepherd Miko has a colourful collection of ties - including a smiley emoji one and a zebra print one - and ‘loves seeing people’s reactions to him’Australian shepherd Miko has a dferent tie for every single day of the week Image: Kelli JonesByNia DaltonSpecialist Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsMeet the happy dog that wears a dferent tie every single day of the week. Australian shepherd Miko is -months-old “makes every single person that crosses his path smile” and doesn’t like to be photographed in the same tie twice. When Miko sticks his head out of the car window, his tie flaps in the wind - and “it’s the most wholesome thing”. The Los Angeles pup loves wearing ties as much as strangers enjoy spotting him in them while heaposs out and about. “Seeing the joy in other people makes Miko happy,” owner Kelli said about her cheery pup.  During lockdown last year, Kelli Jones, based in Los Angeles, Calornia, met with a fellow dog owner who had a collection of pet bandanas for every occasion. “Afterwards, I was scrolling online and spotted a dog tie - I just had to try it,” she said. “I liked the idea of a tie because it wouldn’t be restrictive or uncomfortable for Miko.” And once the pooch started wearing ties outdoors, he never looked back as Kelli noticed the heartwarming effect it had. A stranger in the street spotted his accessory and “smiled so big, he couldn’t look away”. “We loved the positive reaction,” Kelli said. “I noticed that it made people smile when we were out, so we kept doing it to help boost morale during such a tough time.”  When Kelli is driving in the car, Miko will often poke his head out the window. Passersby will often do a “triple take” and point at his tie flapping in the wind. “It’s the most wholesome thing,” Kelli said. It isn’t just strangers that love the ties - Miko enjoys wearing them too. “The tie slips over his head and doesn’t touch the ground. It isn’t heavy so Miko doesn’t really notice when it’s on,” she said. Miko currently has  ties and used to wear them every time the pair left the house. Now, Kelli saves them just for special occasions - until she can find some new ones.  Miko has ties in all prints and patterns, from orange, red and navy to purple and yellow. He has a grey tie with smiley emojis on, one with multicoloured paint splatters and a zebra print one - which is Kelli’s favourite. “I like weird and funky styles,” she said. Kelli has a passion for fashion and likes to colour coordinate her outfits with Miko’s ties. On Miko’s first birthday last year, Kelli traded his usual tie for a bandana and party hat. He had a birthday cake with his name on it and went sheep herding on a ranch in Los Angeles to celebrate. “Miko had worn all the ties we had at home, and I didn’t want to recycle an outfit on his big day,” she said. “I don’t like to be photographed in the same thing twice, so why should he ”  Dog mum Kelli describes Miko as “the sweetest dog” and says he “makes every single person that crosses his path smile”. “He is super cuddly and strong, and I am so grateful for him,” she said. “Sometimes, I just look at him and cry.” Miko loves canine company and enjoys going to the beach and hiking with his doggy friends. He enjoys eating all foods, but his favourite has to be the “pup patty” from In-N-Out Burger. “It’s just a plain meat patty with no salt or bread so it’s safe for dogs,” Kelli said. When Kelli goes out to get coffee, she often gets Miko a “pup cup” because he loves Puppuccinos. story: Hero stepdad, , who couldnt swim dies after jumping in water to save stepdaughterMohammed Zolati, better known by his middle name Reza, did not know how to swim, but still jumped into a river to save his stepdaughter struggling in a deep pool attached to the River Erme on June  Mohammed Zolati, known by is middle name Reza, died after jumping in a river to save his stepdaughter Image: BPM MEDIAByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsA hero stepdad jumped into a river to save his drowning stepdaughter despite being unable to swim. Mohammed Reza Zolati was visiting Longtimber Woods in Ivybridge, Devon, on June   with his two stepchildren when the tragedy happened.An inquest at Plymouth Coroneraposs Court today heard how the young girl managed to get herself out of the water before calling  for help, Devon Live reports.The girl escaped without serious injury but Reza ended up struggling in the water.His stepson stopped a woman for help and other good samaritans attempted to pull Reza out from the popular deep body of water off the River Erme.In a statement, the woman recalled how she and her friend were stopped by the boy while walking their dogs through the woods alongside the river.  The boy then told them his stepfather had been in an accident and led her down a rocky slope to the river. The inquest heard she saw the shape of a body floating under the water so jumped into the water to rescue him while her friend took over the  call from the stepdaughter. She told how she was not a strong swimmer but tried to e down into the water to reach him but was unable to, and said she kept getting swept away. The passerby said: “It was awful.” Even with the help of her friend they were still unable to. Another passerby joined in the effort and it was only when he was assisted by another man that there were able to pull his body onto the rocks and begin CPR. However, Reza was unable to be revived and was confirmed dead at .pm. The initial passerby said: “What happened was tragic but I believe everyone who helped was brilliant. “The little boy and girl deserve some credit as they were so calm and deserve praise too.” The inquest heard the passerby had managed to keep the children and also members of the public away from the scene. Reza, who was born in Iran and was a mechanic before moving to the UK, had been in the water for around  minutes before being rescued and was unable to be revived. A post mortem confirmed the cause of his death was drowning. His GP described Reza as being a ‘fit and well’ man. A police investigation confirmed there were no suspicious circumstances or third party involvement. Detective constable Rachel Walke said: “It appears from all our enquiries it was a tragic accident.” She added that on arrival at the scene, police were initially concerned for the welfare of the children who could not be seen but they were them confirmed as being safe and well at their nearby home. DC Walke confirmed that the pool was a popular area for swimming and that it was deceptively deep and was ‘very dficultapos to get out of once in the water. She added no rescue aids were available at the location. Coroner Ian Arrow, who recorded a conclusion of accidental death, asked the officer to find out who owned the land and that he would then review whether it was appropriate to write to them to review the lack of rescue aids. Following Rezaaposs death, a fundraiser was launched praising his heroic efforts and to raise funds to have his body flown back to his home country and for a memorial service in Devon. The fundraising page said: On Tuesday, June  , Rezaaposs stepdaughter got into some dficulty in the River Erme, located in Long Timber Woods, Ivybridge. Being the hero Reza was, he jumped in and saved her, but unfortunately was unable to save himself as he was a non-swimmer. This goes to show how selfless Reza was, and he showed this every day. He leaves behind his girlfriend and -month-old little girl, as well as lots of friends and colleagues who all saw him as family. We are trying to raise funds so Reza can be flown to his home country, to be laid to rest in peace with the presence of the rest of his family. We are also wanting to hold a memorial service for Reza here in Ivybridge so all who knew him can show their love and respect for him. The gofundme page states that the fundraiser was halted after being reported as aposfraudulentapos and was put under review.
